name: सामान्य नाम or जातिवाचक संज्ञा
description: The current scheme has only one tag (NN) for common nouns without getting into any distinction based on the grammatical  information contained in a given noun word.

name: विशेष नाम or व्यक्तिवाचक संज्ञा
description:
In the context of Indian languages, annotating proper nouns with a separate tag will not be very fruitful from machine learning point of view. Finally, it was decided to have a separate tag for proper nouns for manual
annotation and ignore it for  machine learning algorithms.  Following this decision, the tag NNP is included in the tag set.

name: देश-काल सापेक्ष
description: These words often occur as temporal or spatial arguments of a verb in a given sentence taking the appropriate vibhakti (case marker) Apart from occuring as a nominal expression, they also occur as a part of a postposition along with 'ke'.

name: समापिका-क्रिया
description: Finite verb को हिंदी में परिमित क्रिया कहते हैं। यह क्रिया वाक्य के subject के अनुसार अपना रूप बदलती है और tense का बोध कराती है।

name: असमापिका क्रिया
description: Non-finite verb को हिंदी में अपूर्ण क्रिया कहते हैं। यह क्रिया वाक्य के subject के अनुसार अपना रूप नहीं बदलती है और tense का बोध भी नहीं कराती है।

name: क्रियावाचक or विभक्तिक्षम कृदन्त
description: यह क्रिया को noun के रूप में इस्तेमाल किया जाता है

name: नादानुकारी
description:
Indian languages have a highly productive usage of echo words such as Hindi 'चाय-वाय' ('tea' 'echo'), where 'चाय' is a regular lexical item of Hindi vocabulary and 'वाय' is an echo word indicating the sense “etc” . These words,
on their own, are 'nonsense' words and do not find a place in any dictionary.

name: अभ्यस्त
description:
In this phenomenon of Indian languages, the same word is written twice for
various purposes such as indicating emphasis, deriving a category from another
category etc. eg. छोटे छोटे ('small' 'small'; very small), लाल लाल ('red'
'red'; red), जल्दी जल्दी ('quickyl' 'quickly' ; very quickly)
There are two ways in which such word sequences may be written. They can be
written – (a) separated by a space or (b) separated by a hyphen.
